item.title: Tincture: What is it? How to prepare and use it?
item.description: We will learn what tincture is, how to prepare it at home, and how to use it internally and externally. We also explain what plant you can use for the tincture.

item.title: What are infusions, decoction, and macerate?
item.description: Teas, aqueous extracts of medicinal plants, can be prepared differently, depending on which active ingredients the plant contains. This blog post describes the three most commonly used methods: infusions, decoction, and macerate.

item.title: Common lungwort (*Pulmonaria officinalis*)
item.description: Common lungwort is a medicinal plant that grows in spring and blooms in pink and purple colours. The tincture and tea from Pulmonaria officinalis are used to treat respiratory ailments, coughs and hoarseness.

item.title: Creeping thyme (*Thymus serpyllum*)
item.description: The remarkably fragrant dwarf shrub or the creeping thyme prefers growing on stony ground, and its healing effects are helpful for coughs, colds, and indigestion. Thymus serpyllum can be used to make tea, tincture, or syrup.

item.title: Sweet wormwood (*Artemisia annua*)
item.description: Sweet wormwood is a highly beneficial medicinal plant with proven effects in treating malaria and cancer. It is traditionally used for various ailments and diseases, from viral illnesses to menstrual cramps.
